Lecture 9: Operations on Functions (continued) — Inverse Functions & Implicit vs. Explicit

1. Inverse Functions

1.1 Definition & Existence

An inverse function f−1f^{-1}f−1 “undoes” fff:

f−1(f(x))=x,f(f−1(x))=x.f^{-1}(f(x)) = x,\quad f(f^{-1}(x)) = x. f−1(f(x))=x,f(f−1(x))=x.

A function fff has an inverse if and only if it is one-to-one (injective) and onto its range.

1.2 One-to-One & the Horizontal Line Test

  • One-to-One: each yyy in the range is hit by exactly one xxx.
  • Horizontal Line Test: no horizontal line intersects the graph of fff more than once.

Example:

  • f(x)=x3f(x)=x^3f(x)=x3 passes the test → invertible on R\mathbb{R}R.
  • g(x)=x2g(x)=x^2g(x)=x2 fails on R\mathbb{R}R (two xxx’s for positive yyy) → not invertible unless domain restricted.

2. Finding an Inverse Algebraically

  1. Write y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x).
  2. Swap xxx and yyy: x=f(y)x = f(y)x=f(y).
  3. Solve for yyy; that gives f−1(x)f^{-1}(x)f−1(x).
  4. State domain of f−1f^{-1}f−1 = range of fff, and vice versa.

Example:
f(x)=x−1x+2f(x)=\dfrac{x-1}{x+2}f(x)=x+2x−1​.

y=x−1x+2  ⟹  x=y−1y+2  ⟹  x(y+2)=y−1  ⟹  y(x−1)=−2x−1y = \frac{x-1}{x+2} \;\Longrightarrow\; x = \frac{y-1}{y+2} \;\Longrightarrow\; x(y+2)=y-1 \;\Longrightarrow\; y(x-1) = -2x-1 y=x+2x−1​⟹x=y+2y−1​⟹x(y+2)=y−1⟹y(x−1)=−2x−1

⟹f−1(x)=−2x−1 x−1 .\Longrightarrow \boxed{f^{-1}(x) = \frac{-2x - 1}{\,x - 1\,}.} ⟹f−1(x)=x−1−2x−1​.​

3. Graphing Inverses

  • Plot y=f(x)y = f(x)y=f(x) and y=f−1(x)y = f^{-1}(x)y=f−1(x) together.
  • Draw the line y=xy = xy=x.
  • Observe the mirror symmetry: each point (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) on fff corresponds to (b,a)(b,a)(b,a) on f−1f^{-1}f−1.

Tip: Reflect landmark points (intercepts, extrema) across the line y=xy=xy=x.

4. Implicit vs. Explicit Functions

4.1 Explicit Form

y=f(x).y = f(x). y=f(x).

– Direct formula for yyy.
– Easy to evaluate and plot.

4.2 Implicit Form

F(x,y)=0,F(x,y) = 0, F(x,y)=0,

where solving for yyy may require multiple branches or be impossible in closed form (i.e. no single y=y=y= expression in xxx).

Example (Circle):

x2+y2−9=0.x^2 + y^2 - 9 = 0. x2+y2−9=0.

Explicit branches:
y=+9−x2,y=−9−x2.\displaystyle y = +\sqrt{9 - x^2},\quad y = -\sqrt{9 - x^2}.y=+9−x2​,y=−9−x2​.

5. When to Use Implicit Representation

  • Vertical tangents or cusps (hard to express yyy as a single-valued function).
  • Closed loops or self-intersecting curves.
  • Relations that are not global functions but split into branches.

Example (Folium):
x3+y3−3xy=0\displaystyle x^3 + y^3 - 3xy = 0x3+y3−3xy=0
– Has a loop; no single explicit y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x) covering all points.

Regular Exercises

  1. Inverse Practice
    a) f(x)=3x−5f(x)=3x-5f(x)=3x−5
    b) f(x)=x+2f(x)=\sqrt{x+2}f(x)=x+2​
    c) f(x)=2x+1x−1f(x)=\dfrac{2x+1}{x-1}f(x)=x−12x+1​

  2. Horizontal Line Test
    Determine if each is invertible on R\mathbb{R}R:
    a) y=x2−4y = x^2 - 4y=x2−4
    b) y=2xy = 2^xy=2x
    c) y=log⁡10xy = \log_{10} xy=log10​x

  3. Graph & Reflect

    • Plot f(x)=x3−3xf(x)=x^3 - 3xf(x)=x3−3x.
    • On [1,∞)[1,\infty)[1,∞), find and plot its inverse branch.
    • Include the line y=xy = xy=x.

  4. Inverse Composition
    Let f(x)=2x+3f(x)=2x+3f(x)=2x+3, g(x)=xg(x)=\sqrt{x}g(x)=x​.

    • Compute (f∘g)−1(f\circ g)^{-1}(f∘g)−1.
    • Compare with g−1∘f−1g^{-1}\circ f^{-1}g−1∘f−1.

  5. Implicit → Explicit
    Given x2+xy+y2−7=0x^2 + xy + y^2 - 7 = 0x2+xy+y2−7=0:

    • Solve for yyy to find both branches.
    • State the domain for each branch.

  6. Implicit Curve Analysis
    For x4+y4=8xyx^4 + y^4 = 8xyx4+y4=8xy:

    • Sketch or graph the relation.
    • Identify loops or intersections.
    • Explain why no single explicit y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x) exists.
